Understanding the Goal of Support

As a Registered NDIS Behaviour Support Practitioner, I often tell families that behaviour support isn't just about "stopping" a behaviour—it's about increasing the person's quality of life so that the behaviour is no longer needed.

1. Difficulty Achieving NDIS Goals

If behaviours of concern are acting as a "gatekeeper" to the community, it's time for professional intervention. We look at:

  • Community Access: Is the participant being asked to leave venues or missing out on outings?
  • Skill Building: Are behaviours interrupting the time spent learning new daily living skills?

2. Use of Restrictive Practices

If you find yourself using physical restraint, locking cupboards, or using "PRN" (as-needed) medication frequently, the NDIS requires a regulated Behaviour Support Plan. This ensures these practices are monitored and, eventually, faded out through safer alternatives.

3. Support Team Burnout

High staff turnover is a major red flag. If support workers feel unsafe or confused about how to respond, the resulting inconsistency often makes the participant's behaviour more intense. A unified PBS plan brings the whole team onto the same page.

4. Social and Emotional Withdrawal

Sometimes the sign isn't an "outward" behaviour like hitting or shouting, but an "inward" one—like refusal to leave a room or social withdrawal. Behaviour support helps uncover the sensory or emotional triggers behind this "shutting down."

5. Major Life Transitions

The NDIS journey is full of changes. Whether it's moving from school to work or moving into SDA/SIL accommodation, these transitions are high-stress periods where proactive support can prevent a crisis before it starts.
